questions.question: Which of the following is not a paranasal sinus?
questions.explanation: The pyriform sinus is actually a part of the hypopharynx, not a paranasal sinus.

questions.question: Which is the largest paranasal sinus?
questions.explanation: Maxillary sinus is the largest of paranasal sinuses and occupies the body of maxilla.

questions.question: Which of the following is also known as antrum of Highmore?
questions.explanation: Maxillary sinus is also known as antrum of Highmore.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct about the maxillary sinus?

options.A: Pyramidal in shape with base towards lateral wall of nose and apex towards zygomatic arch
options.B: Pyramidal in shape with base towards zygomatic arch and apex towards lateral wall of nose.

questions.explanation: 309Maxillary sinus is pyramidal in shape, with base towards lateral wall of nose and apex directedlaterally into the zygomatic process of maxilla and sometimes in the zygomatic bone itself.Paranasal sinusesSphenoidFrontalsinussinusEthmoid- sinus.-Nasal-cavity-Maxillary-sinusPharynxOMARROW

questions.question: A pathologist is examining the specimen of a maxillectomy. Which of the following epithelium do you expect to find lining the maxillary sinus?
questions.explanation: Paranasal sinuses are lined by ciliated columnar epithelium with goblet cells, which secrete mucus. They are lined by the mucous membrane, which is continuous with that of the nasal cavity through the ostia of sinuses.

questions.question: Which of the following is most superior in location?
questions.explanation: Frontal sinus is the most superiorly located sinus.It is situated between the inner and outer tables of frontal bone, above and deep to thesupraorbital margin.

questions.question: An anxious father brings his newborn baby to the pediatrician after dropping his baby whenshifting from one arm to another. The pediatrician orders a CT head, which is normal. Whichof the following structures would you not expect to find in the CT?

options.B: Frontal sinusEthmoid sinusd) None of the aboveQuestion 8:Where does the posterior ethmoidal sinus open?a) Superior meatusb) Middle meatus306

questions.explanation: The frontal sinus is absent or rudimentary at birth. Radiologically, the frontal sinus is able to beidentified at 6 years and reaches full size only after puberty.At birth, only the maxillary and ethmoidal sinuses are present and are large enough to beclinically significant. Sphenoid sinus, though may be present, is usually undeveloped andnon-aerated.310SinuseAt birthSMaxillaryPresent4-5 months after birthFirst radiological evidenceReaches adult size by15 yearsEthmoiPresent1 yeardalFrontalAbsent/rudiment6 years12 yearsPost-pubertyarySphenoidPresent4 years14 years

questions.question: Which of the following is true about the sphenoid sinus?

options.A: Present in the greater wing of the sphenoid
options.D: The lateral wall is related to the pituitary gland

questions.explanation: The sphenoid sinus opens into the sphenoethmoidal recess.

questions.question: You are an ENT resident performing endoscopic biopsy from the sphenoid sinus in a COVIDpatient with suspected mucormycosis. Through which of the following areas will you accessthe sinus?
questions.explanation: The sphenoid sinus is accessed through the sphenoethmoidal recess which is situated above thesuperior turbinate.The ostium of the sphenoid sinus can be located endoscopically 1cm above the upper margin ofthe posterior choana near the posterior border of the septum.

questions.question: Optic nerve injury following sinus surgery (FESS) is due to removal of which of the followingethmoidal cells?
questions.explanation: Onodi cell is the posterior ethmoidal cell, related superiorly or laterally to the sphenoid sinus. Theoptic nerve lies in its lateral wall and can be injured while operating in the cells.311RightOnodi cellRight optic canaldehiscenceOption A: Haller cells are a type of ethmoidal cells that are situated on the roof of the maxillarysinus. Sometimes they may enlarge and block the opening of the maxillary sinus leading tomaxillary sinusitis.Haller Cell523Y F 111:2003 M12-3Option B: Agger nasi is an elevation just anterior to the attachment of middle turbinates.Option D: Bulla ethmoidalis is the ethmoidal cell situated behind the uncinate process and formsthe posterior boundary of hiatus semilunaris through which the maxillary, frontal and anteriorethmoidal sinuses drain.

questions.question: While performing functional endoscopic sinus surgery, the surgeon points out the Haller cellsand their clinical significance. Which of the following is correct about these cells?307

options.A: They are related to the maxillary sinus
options.B: They are related to the optic nerve
options.C: They are related to the sphenoid sinus
options.D: They are related to the facial nerve

questions.explanation: Haller cells (infraorbital ethmoidal air cells) are a type of ethmoidal cells that are situated in theroof of the maxillary sinus. Sometimes they may enlarge and block the opening of the maxillary312sinus leading to maxillary sinusitis.The star-marked area in the given CT scan shows the Haller cell*

questions.question: What is occipitomental view with open mouth also known as?
questions.explanation: Occipitomental view is called Water's view. Water's view with an open mouth is known as Pierre'sview. Among the given options, Water's view is the best answer.In Water's view, the patient's head is positioned such that the nose and the chin touch the filmwhile the X-rays are projected from backward. The mouth is usually kept open, which allowsvisualizing the sphenoid sinus.Structures seen in Water's view are:•Maxillary sinuses (seen best)• Frontal sinuses• Sphenoid sinus (if the film is taken with an open mouth)•Zygoma• Zygomatic arch• Nasal bone.• Frontal process of the maxilla•Superior orbital fissure• Infratemporal fossaOther options:Option B: Towne's view is an angled anteroposterior radiograph of the skull. Structures seen arethe petrous part of the pyramids, arcuate eminence, superior semicircular canal, mastoid antrum,internal auditory canal, tympanic cavity, cochlea, and external auditory canal. This view is taken313for acoustic neuroma and apical petrositis.Option C: Law's view is a lateral oblique X-ray view of the mastoid. Structures seen are theexternal auditory canal, mastoid air cells, tegmen, lateral sinus plate, and temporomandibularjoint.Option D: Stenver's view is an X-ray view of the skull where the long axis of the petrous bone isparallel to the film. Structures seen are the entire petrous pyramid, arcuate eminence, internalauditory meatus, labyrinth with its vestibule, cochlea, and mastoid antrum.314
